utterances: You know, the only question I have for Senator Thompson is why the hurry?
Why not take some more time off?
You write this morning that Romney had a tough night at the debate, but who had a good night?
Well, I think Senator McCain had a good night, if perhaps for no other reason than he had the most ground to cover.
Lots of people, both the pundits and regular folks in these early states, have kind of written him off and assumed that his campaign is over.
He's down in the polls.
He doesn't have much money.
He's had lots of staff shakeups.
But he appeared commanding.
His one big issue, the troop surge, Republicans consider that to be going pretty well.
And so he looks like he may have been vindicated in a way and he took advantage of some openings last night.
Rudy Giuliani also did quite well and Mike Huckabee, who has been rising in the polls, who's kind of the distant outside candidate, also did pretty well.
So who among all these candidates has the most to lose from Fred Thompson getting into the race?
In other words, any country can prosecute pirates, no matter where the bandits attack.
That means the U.S.
has the legal authority to bring the captive back here for trial.
Prosecutors could charge him with piracy, or they could charge him with something else, like hostage-taking.
Either crime could bring a life sentence.
Good.
Good.
There is one challenge Biden, Warren and Sanders probably don't have to worry about tonight, and that's a generational challenge.
There are plenty of younger candidates in the race; seven of them will be onstage in Houston.
Although they've tried, so far none of them have been able to dislodge the top three Democrats, all of whom are in their 70s.
Mara Liasson, NPR News, Washington.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Hello wardrobe, something really big has come up, and I don't have a thing to wear.
Just ahead, Governor Palin's makeover and what the women of Slate's XX Factor have to say about it.
First, we're going to begin with a baseball moment from last night's Game One of the World Series.
The playback play announcers got the cameras to focus on a quote that Tampa Bay Rays Manager Joe Madden had posted in the clubhouse.
Here it is.
Rules cannot take the place of character.
That quote from the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
He said much the same again today when speaking to the House Oversight Committee.
As I wrote last March, those of us who have looked to the self interest of lending institutions to protect shareholder's equity, myself especially, are in a state of shocked disbelief.
The Chairman of the Committee, Democrat Henry Waxman, asked Mr. Greenspan about his record of advocating fewer rules, less regulation of the financial industry.
Do you feel that your ideology pushed you to make decisions that you wish you had not made?
Well, remember that what an ideology is is a conceptual framework with the way people deal with reality.
Everyone has one.
You have to - to exist, you need an ideology.
The question is whether it is accurate or not.
And what I'm saying to you is, yes, I found a flaw.
I don't know how significant or permanent it is, but I've been very distressed by that fact.
But, if I may, may I just finish, in answer to the question previously...
You found a flaw in the reality...
A flaw in the model that I perceived is the critical functioning structure that defines how the world works, so to speak.
Alan Greenspan called the current financial crisis a once in a century credit tsunami, but he also said the $700 billion rescue plan should be enough to deal with the credit crisis.
While he spoke, the Treasury Department official who is managing the Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP, he was over in front of the Senate Banking & Housing Committee.
He is Treasury Interim Assistant Secretary Neel Kashkari.
We have accomplished a great deal in a short period of time, but our work is only beginning.
A program as large and complex as this would normally take months or even years to establish.
But we don't have months or years.
Hence, we are moving to implement the TARP as quickly as possible while working to ensure high quality execution.

The top Republican on the committee, Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama, asked why the Treasury Department didn't simply require that the banks actually lend out their billions of federal dollars and not use it for any other purposes.
Here is Kashkari's answer.
We also didn't want to be in a position of micromanaging our banks.

We wanted to create a program where thousands of institutions across our country would volunteer to participate, and if we came with very specific guidelines on, you must do this, you must do that, we were afraid that we would discourage firms, discourage healthy institutions from participating.
We now go to those institutions that will be playing a key role in the government's rescue plan.
The Obama administration has ended the so-called wet foot, dry foot policy which allowed migrants fleeing Cuba without a visa to automatically stay in the United States.
The White House said the change was an important step toward continuing to, quote, ""normalize"" relations with Cuba, a process that began when diplomatic relations were restored in 2014.
More than a million Cubans have come to the United States since the Cuban revolution in 1959.
Carlos Eire was one of 14,000 children airlifted out of Cuba.

In 1962, he wrote of course the National Book Award-winning memoir of his boyhood ""Waiting For Snow In Havana."" He's now a professor of history and religious studies at Yale and joins us from Guilford, Conn.
Carlos, thanks so much for being with us.
Oh, thanks for inviting me to be on your show, Scott.
It's always nice to talk to you.
How do you feel about the policy change?
Well, you know, it's a complicated issue because the wet foot, dry foot policy always had an element of unfairness about it, but it fits in with President Obama's plan for so - normalizing.
I'll put quotation marks around normalizing.
What he had done previously is basically announced to the world that he didn't care about human rights in Cuba.
So now he's made it clear that no Cuban who arrives in the United States can be considered a refugee.
That is, somebody who's fleeing an oppressive regime or fears for their life.
So it's part and parcel of his policy.
And I can kind of see why he waited till the last minute to put this policy into effect because there would have been a lot of pushback from some quarters.

Well, let me ask this - should Cubans be afforded a special status that is not given people who flee crime or violence, say from Mexico or El Salvador in the hemisphere, or desperation and tyranny, as in present day Venezuela?
You know, and the fact that Yemen is a fairly what should I say, it's not an advanced country.
This technology was not developed locally.

That maybe weve won the war there in between the Pakistanis and us, we've closed them down.
And like any good guerilla group, they've picked and left and moved to another country.
So I think that Tim was also asking about possible U.S.
military action.

Well, it seems like all of the candidates have something to lose judging from the way they beat up on him during their debate.
But I think the two candidates that have the most to worry about, first is Mitt Romney.
He's the frontrunner in Iowa and New Hampshire.
He's claiming that he's the true conservative in the race.
That's also something Thompson is going to claim.
Rudy Giuliani is putting a lot of his chips on South Carolina and Thompson polls very well there.
Romney doesn't do so well in South Carolina at the moment.
So for Giuliani, he has to worry about Thompson in South Carolina.
And for Romney, he's got to worry about Thompson in Iowa and New Hampshire.
So they both have something to worry about.
Lots of worries to go around.
John Dickerson of Slate.com, thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
Now, the Opinion Page.
Governments, airlines and aviation authorities around the world are reviewing security after two U.S.-bound packages laced with bombs were shipped from Yemen and intercepted in Dubai and Britain.
The White House calls the threat ongoing.

On Time.com today, intelligence columnist Robert Baer argues this latest bomb plot may show, quote, ""signs of a new, more dangerous wave of terrorism."" The bombs, he says, are more sophisticated, the terrorists more professional, and Yemen may be the new battlefront against al-Qaeda.
If you want to pick Robert Baer's brain on the terror threat in Yemen, call us at 800-989-8255.
Our email address is talk@npr.org, and you can join the conversation at our website, go to npr.org and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Robert Baer is a former Middle East CIA field officer.
He writes Time.com's intelligence column and joins us on the line from Silverton, Colorado.
Welcome back to the show.
It's great to be back.
You wrote that these bombs, you said, have the hallmark of a higher degree of professionalism than we've ever seen come out of al-Qaeda.
Now, we should mention that no one has taken responsibility for these bombs.
But what does this level of sophistication tell you possibly about al-Qaeda in Yemen?
Well, what it reminds me of - this technology goes back to the '80s, and it's an explosive called PETN.
It's got what's called a high brisance.
It's very lethal.
But more than anything, it's malleable.
And you can, as we saw in these bombs, you can put into the ink of a toner cartridge.
In the '80s, a Palestinian who devised this method actually rolled PETN, and that's a technical term, and put it in the walls of a Samsonite suitcase.
Hezbollah made it looked like olives and so forth.
It is the ideal explosive for terrorists.
But if it's been around since the '80s, what's (unintelligible)?
Well - but I've never seen it crisscross with al-Qaeda or Yemen.
I mean, it's not something you think about when you come to Yemen.
And what I think worries a lot of people that I've talked to is this old technology which was - we've never really defeated it, has been picked up by al-Qaeda, possibly in Yemen.
This, of course, is an assessment.
I wouldn't know that for a fact, but this was a very sophisticated bomb found on these two airplanes.
Now, officials in Qatar, where one of the bombs was intercepted, have been quoted as saying that these hidden bombs were undetectable by X-ray screening or sniffer dogs.
Do we have any...
Oh, I think that's absolutely correct.
I mean, you would have to run them through a nitrogen sniffer.
You'd have to open up the toner cartridges to really get a good sample.
And there's other techniques that are more advanced.
And we have to remember that the security in Doha, Qatar, is very, very good.
I mean, they've put a lot of money into it.
They are on top of all advancements.
We're not talking about a Third World airport that it slipped through here.
These bombs could slip through our airports as well.
Thus very worrying.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But, is that a new thing that...
What worries...
